topics.title: How To Invest Like the Best
topics.content:
#### What you will learn
• The four habits shared by elite investors.
• How diversification, compounding, and psychology work together.
• A simple blueprint for creating your own lifetime investing plan.

#### Key concepts explained
1. **Pay-yourself-first** – Treat investing as a non-negotiable bill. Automate transfers the morning your salary arrives so saving is effortless.
2. **Emergency fund first** – Park 3–6 months of expenses in a high-yield account to avoid panic-selling when life happens.
3. **Asset allocation** – Split money between equities, bonds, and cash using an age-based glide path (e.g., 110 − your age = % in stocks).
4. **Time in the market > timing the market** – Missing just the 10 best trading days per decade typically halves total returns.

#### Step-by-step blueprint
1. Open a low-cost brokerage and a separate savings account.
2. Calculate your “investable surplus” (income − essential bills − emergency fund contribution).
3. Set up an automatic monthly purchase into a broad index ETF (e.g., S&P 500) and a local-market fund for geographic balance.
4. Rebalance annually: sell overweight winners, buy laggards to restore target percentages.
5. Review goals each January—then ignore day-to-day noise.

#### Real-world case study
Warren Buffett’s 1988 Coca-Cola buy: \$1 billion turned into \$20 billion+ by 2025—almost entirely through reinvested dividends and patient holding.

#### Activity
Write your own one-page “Investment Policy Statement” covering risk tolerance, target allocation, and automatic contribution size. Share with a study buddy for accountability.

#### Common pitfalls
✘ Trading every headline.  
✘ Concentrating in a single hot sector.  
✘ Investing before building an emergency cushion.

#### Takeaway
Elite investors are methodical, boring, and relentlessly long-term. Adopt their systems, not their stock picks.

topics.title: Why Should I Invest?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How inflation quietly erodes idle cash.  
• The math of compound growth (Rule of 72).  
• Historical returns of stocks vs. bonds vs. savings accounts.

#### Key concepts explained
1. **Inflation** – At 3 % inflation, ₦1 000 today buys only ₦744 worth of goods in 10 years. Investing must outpace this.
2. **Compounding** – Earnings are reinvested so growth accelerates. The Rule of 72 estimates doubling time: 72 ÷ annual % return.
3. **Opportunity cost** – Every naira left dormant forfeits potential gains.

#### Historical perspective
• Average annual real (after-inflation) return 1926-2024:  
 – U.S. stocks ~7 %  
 – Government bonds ~2 %  
 – Cash ~0 %  
A long-term stock investor saw purchasing power quadruple every 20–25 years; a saver barely kept up.

#### Worked example
Invest ₦100 000 yearly at 8 %. Years to ₦10 million (future naira): ~18. Stop after the first five years and leave the money to grow: final pot halves to ~₦5 million—showing the cost of delaying.

#### Interactive exercise
Open any compound-interest calculator and test how delaying by 5 or 10 years changes your results. Screenshot the graph for your notes.

#### Common pitfalls
✘ Confusing high nominal returns with high real returns (always subtract inflation).  
✘ Thinking investing is “too risky” but ignoring the guaranteed loss of purchasing power in cash.

#### Takeaway
Investing turns time into a money-making ally; procrastination turns it into your biggest expense.

topics.title: How Should I Organize My Income?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Three beginner-friendly budgeting frameworks.  
• How to layer debt payoff, saving, and investing without overwhelm.  
• Practical tools for automating cash flow.

#### Frameworks compared
| Framework | Core Idea | Best For |
|-----------|-----------|----------|
| **50/30/20** | 50 % needs, 30 % wants, 20 % future you | Most beginners |
| **Zero-based** | Assign every naira a job so income − outgo = 0 | Detail lovers |
| **80/20 (Pay-yourself-first)** | Save 20 % up front; spend the rest guilt-free | People who hate tracking |

#### Building the “Money Map”
1. **Income hub** – Salary lands here.  
2. **Safety bucket** – Auto-transfer to emergency fund and sinking funds.  
3. **Wealth bucket** – Auto-invest into ETFs or retirement plans.  
4. **Lifestyle bucket** – Debit card for day-to-day spending.

#### Debt snowball vs. avalanche
• **Snowball** – Pay smallest balance first → quick wins, boosts motivation.  
• **Avalanche** – Pay highest-interest first → mathematically cheapest.  
Choose the style that keeps you consistent.

#### Activity
Label four real bank accounts or digital “spaces” with the buckets above. Move a symbolic ₦500 into each to feel the system working.

#### Pitfalls & fixes
✘ Relying on memory; **fix:** automate.  
✘ Forgetting to revisit percentages when income changes; **fix:** schedule a quarterly money date.

#### Takeaway
A clear, automated income system frees your brain for bigger investing decisions.

topics.title: What Is a Stock?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• The legal meaning of “share of ownership.”  
• How common vs. preferred shares differ.  
• Ways shareholders can earn returns.

#### Share structure 101
| Type | Rights | Typical Owners |
|------|--------|----------------|
| **Common** | Vote, potential dividends, last in liquidation | Public investors |
| **Preferred** | No vote, fixed dividends, priority in liquidation | Institutions, income seekers |

#### Rights embedded in a share
1. **Voting** – Elect board members, approve mergers.  
2. **Dividends** – Cash or stock payouts (not guaranteed).  
3. **Residual claim** – Receive assets if the company is liquidated (after creditors).

#### Order of claims in liquidation
Creditors → Bondholders → Preferred → Common. Common shareholders therefore demand higher expected returns.

#### Example: Apple Inc.
• 16 billion diluted shares outstanding. Buying 1 share ≈ 0.000000006 % of Apple. Yet over 20 years, that sliver compounded 25 x in price plus dividends.

#### Quiz
True/False – A company must distribute profits as dividends. (False.)

#### Takeaway
Owning stock makes you a business partner, with the same exposure to both profits and pitfalls.

topics.title: What Is an ETF?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How ETFs marry diversification with stock-like convenience.  
• The mechanics of the creation-redemption process that keeps prices in line.  
• Cost, tax, and liquidity considerations.

#### Anatomy of an ETF
1. **Basket** – Holds dozens to thousands of securities following an index (e.g., S&P 500) or theme (e.g., clean energy).  
2. **Share** – Trades intraday on an exchange at market prices.  
3. **Authorized Participants (APs)** – Large institutions that swap baskets for ETF shares, arbitraging away pricing gaps.

#### Passive vs. active ETFs
• **Passive** – Track an index; lower fees (often 0.03 %–0.10 %).  
• **Active** – Portfolio manager aims to outperform; higher fees (0.5 %+), may have higher turnover.

#### Tracking error
Small difference between ETF return and index return caused by fees, sampling, or cash drag. Look for < 0.2 % annually.

#### Expense ratio impact
Paying 1 % vs. 0.05 % on a ₦5 million portfolio over 30 years (8 % growth) costs ≈ ₦3 million in lost gains—nearly as much as your original investment!

#### Activity
Compare two ETFs that track the same index but charge different fees. Use an online calculator to estimate 20-year cost difference.

#### Takeaway
ETFs give small investors instant diversification, but fees and liquidity require a quick check before clicking “buy.”

topics.title: What Is the Stock Market?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How exchanges, brokers, and clearinghouses interact.  
• The flow of an order from your phone to the market.  
• Key terms: bid, ask, spread, market maker.

#### Market plumbing in 60 seconds
1. Place a **market order** in your broker app.  
2. Order routes to an exchange (e.g., NYSE).  
3. A **market maker** matches your buy with someone’s sell and quotes two prices: **bid** (buy) and **ask** (sell).  
4. After execution, the trade clears through a clearinghouse (DTCC) on **T+2** (moving to T+1 in 2025).

#### Types of orders
| Order | When to use |
|-------|-------------|
| Market | Immediate fill, price uncertainty |
| Limit  | Control price, no guarantee of fill |
| Stop-loss | Exit automatically if price drops below X |

#### After-hours & pre-market
Lower liquidity widens spreads; beginners should stick to regular hours.

#### Circuit breakers
If an index drops 7 %, 13 %, or 20 % in a single day, exchanges pause trading to calm panic.

#### Activity
Look up today’s bid-ask spread for two large-cap stocks and two thinly traded small-caps. Notice the cost of illiquidity.

#### Takeaway
The stock market is a sophisticated but highly efficient auction. Understanding its mechanics helps you trade with confidence and lower costs.

topics.title: What Are Stock Indexes?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• The purpose of indexes as economic thermometers.  
• Different weighting schemes and how they affect performance.  
• How index rebalancing works.

#### Weighting methods
| Method | Example | Quirk |
|--------|---------|-------|
| Market-cap | S&P 500 | Bigger companies dominate |
| Price-weight | Dow Jones 30 | \$400 stock moves index more than \$40 stock |
| Equal-weight | RSP ETF | Small stocks get same weight as giants |

#### Rebalancing
Most indexes revisit weights quarterly; some (e.g., Nasdaq-100) limit single-company weightings to maintain diversification.

#### Using indexes
1. **Benchmark** – Compare your portfolio to the S&P 500 or a local index.  
2. **Invest** – Buy index funds/ETFs that replicate the basket.  
3. **Trade derivatives** – Futures and options on indexes help hedge risk (advanced).

#### Activity
Pick any index and list its top 10 holdings and percentages. How concentrated is it? Would you feel comfortable having 40 % in the top two names?

#### Takeaway
Indexes simplify market noise into a single number—but the recipe (weighting) changes the flavor of that number.

topics.title: What Are IPOs?
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Step-by-step journey from private startup to publicly traded giant.  
• Pricing mechanics and the “first-day pop.”  
• How lock-ups and quiet periods protect early investors.

#### IPO timeline
1. Board votes to pursue an IPO; hire investment banks as **underwriters**.  
2. File an S-1 prospectus; disclose financials, risks, use of proceeds.  
3. **Roadshow** – management pitches to institutional investors.  
4. Price range set; underwriters allocate shares.  
5. Shares debut; trading begins on the exchange.  
6. **Lock-up period** (90–180 days) restricts insiders from selling en masse.

#### Why IPOs are often under-priced
Banks aim for a successful first-day market; a 10–20 % “pop” rewards early buyers but leaves cash on the table for the company.

#### Alternatives to traditional IPO
• **Direct listing** – skips underwriters; price set purely by market.  
• **SPAC merger** – go public via a shell company.  
• **Crowd-funded IPO** – sell small blocks to retail investors pre-listing.

#### Activity
Download any recent S-1 filing (e.g., Airbnb 2020) and highlight: revenue growth, net loss, and stated “use of proceeds.”

#### Takeaway
An IPO is a pivotal publicity and fundraising event—not an automatic bargain. Always read the prospectus.

topics.title: Bull vs. Bear Markets
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Statistical definitions vs. psychological reality of market cycles.  
• Economic indicators that often precede bulls and bears.  
• Portfolio moves to consider in each phase.

#### Market cycle psychology
1. **Optimism → Euphoria** (Bull) – valuations stretch, IPOs boom.  
2. **Anxiety → Capitulation** (Bear) – prices free-fall, news feels apocalyptic.  
3. **Despair → Hope** – smart money re-enters, cycle resets.

#### Economic clues
| Indicator | Bull Signal | Bear Signal |
|-----------|------------|-------------|
| GDP | Rising > 3 % | Contracting |
| Unemployment | Falling | Rising sharply |
| Yield curve | Normal/steep | Inverted |

#### Strategies
• **Bull** – Dollar-cost average, ride winners, but rebalance to avoid concentration.  
• **Bear** – Revisit emergency fund, maintain long horizon, harvest tax losses, consider adding defensive sectors (consumer staples, utilities).

#### Historical examples
• Dot-com Bust 2000-2002: −49 % S&P 500.  
• Global Financial Crisis 2008-2009: −56 %.  
• COVID-19 Crash 2020: −34 % in 33 days—fastest bear ever, followed by record bull.

#### Activity
Chart the S&P 500 over the past 25 years and mark bull and bear phases; note average length and magnitude.

#### Takeaway
Bull and bear markets are inevitable. Building a rules-based response plan beats guessing when the next turn arrives.

topics.title: Market Capitalization
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How to compute market cap and why it matters.  
• The difference between market cap and enterprise value.  
• How cap buckets map to risk and return.

#### Market cap formula
Share Price × Shares Outstanding = Market Capitalization.

#### Enterprise value (EV)
EV = Market Cap + Total Debt − Cash. EV reflects *total* price to buy the company, important for takeovers and valuation.

#### Cap buckets & style boxes
| Bucket | Cap Range | Typical Traits |
|--------|-----------|----------------|
| Mega | > $200 B | Stable, global, dividend payers |
| Large | $10 B–$200 B | Blue-chips, broad analyst coverage |
| Mid | $2 B–$10 B | Growth runway, medium volatility |
| Small | $300 M–$2 B | Higher growth & risk |
| Micro | < $300 M | Illiquid, speculative |

#### Free-float adjustment
Indexes often exclude insider-controlled shares to better reflect actual tradeable supply.

#### Activity
Pick three companies of different cap sizes. Calculate market cap, EV, and dividend yield. Which looks riskiest? Why?

#### Takeaway
Market cap is a fast size gauge, but enterprise value and free-float give deeper insight into market perception and deal pricing.

topics.title: Growth vs. Value Stocks
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Fundamental differences between growth and value investing styles.  
• Metrics screens to identify each.  
• How style rotation influences performance.

#### Growth profile
• Revenue & EPS growth ≥ 15 % YoY.  
• High P/E, P/S, PEG ratios (> 2).  
• Often reinvest earnings; low or no dividends.  
• Examples: cloud-software, biotech startups.

#### Value profile
• Low P/E (below sector average), high dividend yield.  
• Stable cash flows; often mature industries.  
• May face temporary challenges that depress price.  
• Examples: banks trading at 0.8 × book value.

#### PEG ratio (P/E ÷ Growth rate)
A growth stock with P/E 40 and 40 % growth has PEG = 1 → fairly priced by this measure.

#### Style rotation
Over long horizons value and growth deliver similar returns but at different times. 2020-2023 favored growth; 2024-2025 value rebounded as rates rose.

#### Activity
Screen 20 stocks for P/E and five-year EPS growth. Classify each as growth, value, or blend.

#### Takeaway
Owning both styles helps balance economic cycles and investor sentiment swings.

topics.title: Do’s & Don’ts of Investing
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Behavioral biases that wreck portfolios.  
• Proven habits that compound returns.  
• A checklist to audit your own behavior.

#### Do’s
✔ Diversify across sectors, geographies, and asset classes.  
✔ Keep costs low (seek ETFs < 0.15 % expense ratio).  
✔ Reinvest dividends automatically.  
✔ Document each trade’s thesis in a journal.

#### Don’ts
✘ React emotionally to headlines (loss aversion).  
✘ Chase meme stocks or tips without research (FOMO).  
✘ Ignore taxes and transaction fees.  
✘ Borrow excessively to invest.

#### Behavioral biases in action
• **Overconfidence** – Assuming your pick is “obvious,” skipping diversification.  
• **Recency bias** – Expecting yesterday’s winner to soar forever.  
• **Confirmation bias** – Only reading news that supports your view.

#### Self-audit checklist
1. Did I diversify adequately?  
2. Do I know my expense ratios?  
3. Is my thesis written down?  
4. Have I set an exit plan (time or fundamental)?

#### Takeaway
Mastering your own psychology often beats mastering complex models.

topics.title: How To Make Money in the Stock Market
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• The components of total return.  
• Income strategies beyond simple buy-and-hold.  
• How taxes influence net gains.

#### Total return formula
Price Appreciation + Dividends + Other cash distributions − Taxes − Fees.

#### Dividend Reinvestment Plans (DRIPs)
Automatically convert cash dividends into additional shares—boosts compounding and dollar-cost averages purchase price.

#### Covered-call income (advanced)
Sell call options on a stock you own to collect premium; caps upside but generates cash flow.

#### Tax efficiency tips (generalized)
• Hold > 1 year to qualify for lower capital-gains tax rates (jurisdiction dependent).  
• Use tax-advantaged retirement accounts when available.  
• Harvest losses to offset gains.

#### Worked scenario
₦1 million in a 3 % dividend stock reinvested and 6 % price growth → 9 % total return ≈ ₦90 000 first year, and more each subsequent year as the base compounds.

#### Activity
Use an online DRIP calculator to see 10-, 20-, and 30-year outcomes for a dividend aristocrat of your choice.

#### Takeaway
Understanding—and reinvesting—every component of return is the fastest legal way to snowball wealth.

topics.title: Earnings Per Share (EPS)
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How basic vs. diluted EPS are calculated.  
• Why share buybacks often boost EPS.  
• Limits of EPS as a stand-alone metric.

#### Calculating basic EPS
(Net Profit − Preferred Dividends) ÷ Weighted-average shares.

#### Diluted EPS
Accounts for options, warrants, and convertible securities that could become common shares. Provides a conservative profitability view.

#### Buyback effect
Reducing share count via buybacks lifts EPS even if profit is flat—important to separate *real* growth from “per-share” optics.

#### Red flags
• EPS up but revenue flat → may rely on buybacks or cost-cutting.  
• One-time gains (asset sales) inflating net income.  
• Seasonal businesses—compare to same quarter last year, not prior quarter.

#### Activity
Find a company whose EPS rose last year but whose total profit fell—explain why in one paragraph.

#### Takeaway
EPS is a powerful snapshot but only when paired with revenue, cash flow, and share-count trends.

topics.title: Price-to-Earnings (P/E) Ratio
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• Trailing vs. forward P/E.  
• Sector-specific ‘normal’ ranges.  
• When a low P/E is *not* a bargain.

#### Variants
| Variant | Formula | Use |
|---------|---------|-----|
| **Trailing-12-month** | Price ÷ last 12 mo EPS | Widely cited |
| **Forward** | Price ÷ next-year EPS estimate | Growth forecasting |
| **CAPE (Shiller)** | Price ÷ 10-yr inflation-adjusted EPS | Smooths cycles |

#### Danger zones
• Low P/E with shrinking sales (value trap).  
• Very high P/E in cyclical firms near peak earnings (energy, semiconductors).

#### PEG ratio refresher
PEG < 1 can indicate undervaluation relative to growth; > 2 may imply overpricing.

#### Activity
Compare the forward P/E of two rival firms. How much extra are investors willing to pay for the faster-growing company? Is the premium justified?

#### Takeaway
P/E is a quick filter—pass candidates through deeper analyses before buying.

topics.title: Dividend Yield
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How to compute and interpret dividend yield.  
• Payout ratio and dividend safety signals.  
• Dividend growth investing basics.

#### Key formulas
Dividend Yield = Annual Dividend per Share ÷ Price.  
Payout Ratio = Dividends ÷ Net Income (or Free Cash Flow).

#### Safety checkpoints
• **Payout Ratio < 60 %** for most sectors (utilities can run higher).  
• Stable or rising free cash flow.  
• Long dividend streak (e.g., Dividend Aristocrats ≥ 25 years).

#### Dividend growth rate (DGR)
A 5 % yield growing 8 % annually beats a flat 7 % yield in less than 9 years—illustrating the power of rising payouts.

#### Dates to know
• **Ex-dividend** – Buy before this date to receive the next dividend.  
• **Record date** – Company determines who gets paid.  
• **Payment date** – Cash hits your account.

#### Activity
Pick three high-yield stocks. Check payout ratios and 5-year DGR. Which looks safest?

#### Takeaway
Yield alone can mislead; sustainability and growth rate turn a payout into a compounding machine.

topics.title: Debt-to-Equity (D/E) Ratio
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• How leverage amplifies both gains and losses.  
• Sector norms for D/E.  
• Complementary leverage metrics.

#### Interpreting D/E
D/E = Total Liabilities ÷ Shareholders’ Equity.  
> 1 means more debt than equity; < 1 means majority equity financing.

#### Sector context
| Sector | Typical D/E |
|--------|-------------|
| Utilities | 1.0–2.5 |
| Tech | 0.2–0.8 |
| Financials | Varies; regulation caps ratios |

#### Supporting ratios
• **Interest-coverage** = EBIT ÷ Interest Expense (> 5 is healthy).  
• **Debt/EBITDA** (< 3 preferred for non-utilities).

#### Example
Company A: D/E = 2 → interest-coverage = 1.5 → red flag; even small earnings drop may jeopardize bond covenants.

#### Activity
Choose a favorite company; compare its D/E, interest-coverage, and debt/EBITDA to sector averages. Summarize risk in three sentences.

#### Takeaway
Leverage can turbocharge returns or sink a firm; use multiple ratios and sector benchmarks to judge prudently.

topics.title: How To Know What Stocks to Buy
topics.content:
#### What you’ll learn
• A repeatable five-step research process.  
• Qualitative vs. quantitative filters.  
• Tools for building and tracking a watch-list.

#### Five-step process
1. **Understand the business** – Read the 10-K summary; explain revenue drivers like you’re teaching a friend.
2. **Check financial strength** – Look for rising revenue, healthy gross margin, low leverage.
3. **Value the company** – Compare P/E, EV/EBITDA, and discounted cash-flow (DCF) to peers.
4. **Assess moat & management** – Search for network effects, patents, cost advantages; review CEO tenure and insider ownership.
5. **Identify catalysts** – New product cycles, regulatory approvals, or margin expansion that could unlock value.

#### Quantitative screens
| Metric | Minimum | Why |
|--------|---------|-----|
| ROE | > 15 % | Capital efficiency |
| Gross Margin | > 40 % | Pricing power |
| Debt/EBITDA | < 2 | Balance-sheet safety |

#### Tools
• Free: Yahoo Finance, Finviz screener, annual-report PDFs.  
• Premium: Morningstar, Value Line for deeper analytics.

#### Activity
Select two companies in the same industry. Complete the five-step checklist and decide which offers a better risk-adjusted opportunity.

#### Takeaway
Stock picking is detective work—blend numbers, narrative, and catalysts to build conviction before you click “buy.”
